title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [3–24 january 1871]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [3–24 January 1871]
text: 10 Jan 1871tuesdayTuesday afternoonwell walterWalter dearhow are you by this time i got your letter on saturdaySaturday we are all about the same we have had very cold weather here indeed georgeGeorge came home again last saturdaySaturday night he had to come to see about the property he sold to mrsMrs. stearsSteers as there is assesmentsassessments found against the property and Lott wrote to him to see to it immediately so he came on so much for mrMr. greenwood sGreenwood's search and when stearsStears bought it he had Lott to make a searshsearch i gessguess they didentdidn't searshsearch very deep georgeGeorge went back this morning by th 7 oclocko'clock train he left it for Lott to settle against he come again it will be considerable to pay) mrsMrs. stears was here the other day she dontdon't seem to get along very well her son is discharged from the water board with many others there is very many out of employment this winter georgeGeorge says any time that its conveinentconvenient for you waltWalt to pay that money you had of him he aintain't in a huryhurry for it if you come on in febuaryFebruary that will be time enoughfenough or after that) i sent han the letter i spoke of when georgeGeorge was home before and the 5 dollardollars he gave me for her) and to day i received one of mrMr. HeydesHeyde's epistles rather the worst one i have received yet i looked it over and threw it in the stove the most insulting but let it go)i have not heard any thing more from matyMatty whether she is coming or not the weather is so cold it will beebe quite an undertaking to come so far)i am about as usual quite smart only i got up so early to get georgesGeorge's breakfast that i feel stupid enoughfenough)i hope this will find you well walterWalter dear Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [3–24 January 1871]
